children.value: Demo
We will approximate the integral of the function
f(x)=e^{\sin 7x}
children.html: f(x)=esin⁡7xf(x)=e^{\sin 7x}f(x)=esin7x

children.value: over the interval

children.html: [0,2][0,2][0,2]

children.value: In lieu of the exact value, we use the
QuadGK
package to find an accurate result.

```{tip}
:class: dropdown
If a function has multiple return values, you can use an underscore `_` to indicate a  return value you want to ignore.
```
Here is the trapezoid result at

children.html: n=40n=40n=40

children.value: , and its error.

T, t, y = FNC.trapezoid(f, a, b, 40)
@show (T, Q - T);
In order to check the order of accuracy, we increase
n
children.html: nnn

children.value: by orders of magnitude and observe how the error decreases.

n = [10^n for n in 1:5]
err = zeros(length(n))
for (k, n) in enumerate(n)
    T, t, y = FNC.trapezoid(f, a, b, n)
    err[k] = Q - T
end
@pt :header=["n", "error"] [n err]

text/html.content:
n error
10.0 0.0120254
100.0 0.000147305
1000.0 1.47415e-6
10000.0 1.47416e-8
100000.0 1.47416e-10

children.value: Each increase by a factor of 10 in
n
children.html: nnn

children.value: cuts the error by a factor of about 100, which is consistent with second-order convergence. Another check is that a log-log graph should give a line of slope
as
n\to\infty
children.html: n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞

children.value:
plot(n, abs.(err);
    m=:o, label="results",
    xaxis=(:log10, L"n"),  yaxis=(:log10, "error"),
    title="Convergence of trapezoidal integration")

# Add line for perfect 2nd order.
plot!(n, 3e-3 * (n / n[1]) .^ (-2), l=:dash, label=L"O(n^{-2})")
